samples.claim: The mitochondria is often referred to as the powerhouse of the cell because it produces ATP through cellular respiration.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792 kilometers per second.
The Great Wall of China was primarily built during the Ming Dynasty.
The Amazon River flows primarily through Brazil before emptying into the Atlantic Ocean.
DNA is a double-stranded helix composed of nucleotides containing adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine.
The first commercially successful smartphone was the Apple iPhone, released in 2007.
Mount Everest is the tallest mountain on Earth, measured from sea level.
The periodic table was organized by Dmitri Mendeleev in 1869, arranged by atomic number.
Photosynthesis in plants converts carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen using sunlight.
The Wright Brothers made their first successful powered flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in 1903.
The human body has 206 bones in adulthood.
The transistor was invented at Bell Labs in 1947.
The Nile River is the longest river in the world, flowing northward through northeastern Africa.
World War I began in 1914 following the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo.
Absolute zero is defined as -273.15 degrees Celsius, or 0 Kelvin.
The human genome contains approximately 3 billion base pairs and around 25,000 protein-coding genes.
The capital of Australia is Sydney, which is also the country's most populous city.
Marie Curie was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, receiving it in Chemistry in 1903.
The internet's foundational protocol, TCP/IP, was developed primarily by Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn.
Neurons in the human brain transmit signals electrically along axons and chemically across synapses.
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet by the International Astronomical Union in 2006.
The Berlin Wall fell in November 1991, marking the end of the Cold War.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world and is located in northern Africa.
Python programming language was created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991.
Vaccines work by introducing a weakened or inactivated pathogen to stimulate an immune response.
The Roman Empire fell in 476 AD when Romulus Augustulus was deposed by Odoacer.
Lake Superior is the largest of the Great Lakes by both surface area and volume.
Mendeleev organized the periodic table by atomic weight, not atomic number.
CRISPR-Cas9 is a gene-editing tool originally derived from a bacterial immune defense mechanism.
The Apollo 11 mission landed on the Moon in July 1969, with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin becoming the first humans to walk on the lunar surface.
Mitochondria produce ATP through cellular respiration via the electron transport chain in the inner mitochondrial membrane.
William the Conqueror defeated King Harold II at the Battle of Hastings in 1066.
Marie Curie was the first person to win Nobel Prizes in two different scientific disciplines.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 300,000 kilometers per second.
The double helix structure of DNA was first described by Watson and Crick in 1953, aided by Franklin's X-ray crystallography.
The Great Wall of China was primarily constructed during the Ming Dynasty.
The light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis occur in the thylakoid membranes and produce ATP and NADPH.
The Black Death killed an estimated one-third to one-half of Europe's population in the 14th century.
Newton published his three laws of motion in Principia Mathematica in 1687.
The human genome contains approximately 3 billion base pairs spread across 23 pairs of chromosomes.
In E=mc², 'c' represents the speed of sound.
The Amazon River is the longest river in the world.
Fleming identified penicillin as being produced by Aspergillus niger.
The Roman Colosseum was commissioned by Emperor Augustus.
Mendeleev arranged elements in the periodic table by increasing atomic number.
Neil Armstrong landed on the Moon with Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins as part of the crew.
Darwin collaborated closely with Wallace throughout the development of evolution by natural selection.
Water reaches its maximum density at 0 degrees Celsius, the freezing point.
Napoleon crowned himself Emperor of France in 1804.
Glass has a refractive index of approximately 2.5.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792,458 meters per second.
Planck's constant is approximately 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ joule-seconds.
The gravitational constant G is approximately 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg².
The elementary charge of an electron is approximately 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ coulombs.
The boiling point of water at standard atmospheric pressure is 100°C (373.15 K).
The atomic mass of carbon-12 is exactly 12 unified atomic mass units by definition.
The density of liquid water at 4°C is approximately 1000 kg/m³ (1 g/cm³).
The average distance from Earth to the Sun (1 AU) is approximately 149,597,870.7 kilometers.
The diameter of the Milky Way galaxy is approximately 100,000 light-years.
The Moon's mean orbital distance from Earth is approximately 384,400 kilometers.
The Wright brothers made their first powered flight at Kitty Hawk on December 17, 1903.
The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1889 and stands 330 meters tall including its antenna.
The world population reached 8 billion people in November 2022.
The melting point of pure iron at standard pressure is approximately 1538°C.
The Avogadro constant is approximately 6.022 × 10²³ per mole.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 186,000 miles per hour.
Planck's constant is approximately 6.626 × 10⁻²⁷ joule-seconds.
The boiling point of ethanol at standard pressure is 100°C.
The atomic number of gold is 78.
The density of aluminum is approximately 8.9 g/cm³.
The average distance from Earth to the Moon is approximately 1.2 million kilometers.
The diameter of the observable universe is approximately 46 million light-years.
Mars has a mean orbital distance from the Sun of approximately 1.0 AU.
The Wright brothers made their first powered flight on December 17, 1901.
The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1901 for the Paris World's Fair.
The Burj Khalifa stands 928 meters tall, making it the world's tallest building.
The world population first exceeded 1 billion people in approximately 1900.
The population of the United States surpassed 400 million in 2020.
The melting point of pure tungsten is approximately 1083°C, the highest of all metals.
The Avogadro constant is approximately 6.022 × 10²⁶ per mole.
Rosalind Franklin obtained her PhD from Cambridge University in 1945, where she studied the physical chemistry of coal microstructure.
Lynn Margulis published her endosymbiotic theory paper 'On the Origin of Mitosing Cells' in the Journal of Theoretical Biology in 1967.
George Dantzig developed the simplex algorithm for linear programming while working at the Air Force's Project SCOOP in the late 1940s.
Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar calculated the maximum mass of a stable white dwarf star, now called the Chandrasekhar limit, to be approximately 1.4 solar masses.
Emmy Noether proved her famous theorem connecting symmetries and conservation laws in 1915, published in 1918 in Nachrichten von der Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Göttingen.
Chien-Shiung Wu conducted the experiment in 1956 that disproved the conservation of parity in weak nuclear interactions, confirming the theoretical prediction by Lee and Yang.
Barbara McClintock received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1983 for her discovery of transposable genetic elements, becoming the first woman to win that prize unshared.
Alan Turing published 'Computing Machinery and Intelligence' in the journal Mind in 1950, introducing the concept now known as the Turing Test.
Hedy Lamarr, along with composer George Antheil, patented a frequency-hopping spread spectrum communication technique in 1942 originally intended to make radio-guided torpedoes harder to detect.
Claude Shannon published 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication' in the Bell System Technical Journal in 1948, founding the field of information theory.
Lynn Margulis received her PhD from the University of California, Berkeley in 1965, where her advisor was Max Delbruck.
Chien-Shiung Wu was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1957 alongside Tsung-Dao Lee and Chen-Ning Yang for the parity violation experiment.
George Dantzig's famous story of mistakenly solving two unsolved statistics problems as homework occurred when he was a graduate student at Princeton under Harold Hotelling.
Emmy Noether completed her PhD at the University of Berlin in 1907 under the supervision of Felix Klein.
Barbara McClintock conducted her Nobel Prize-winning research on transposable elements primarily using wheat as her model organism.
Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar shared the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physics with William Fowler, and the prize was awarded for his work on stellar nucleosynthesis.
Claude Shannon received his PhD from MIT in 1940, with a dissertation on the algebra of genetics supervised by Vannevar Bush.
Alan Turing's 1936 paper 'On Computable Numbers, with an Application to the Entscheidungsproblem' was published in the Proceedings of the Royal Society.
Rosalind Franklin's X-ray diffraction image of DNA, known as Photo 51, was taken by Franklin herself in 1952 and showed the A-form of DNA fiber.

Hedy Lamarr's frequency-hopping patent expired in 1959 before the U.S. military adopted the technology, meaning she never received any financial compensation or official recognition during her lifetime.
It is widely believed that the Great Wall of China is visible from space with the naked eye.
Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius at standard atmospheric pressure.
Research suggests that humans only use about 10% of their brain capacity at any given time.
Approximately 78% of Earth's atmosphere is composed of nitrogen.
According to most sources, Napoleon Bonaparte was unusually short for his era, standing around 5 feet 2 inches.
Research suggests that DNA carries genetic information through sequences of four nucleotide bases: adenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine.
It is widely believed that lightning never strikes the same place twice.
Approximately 71% of Earth's surface is covered by water.
According to most sources, the human body has 206 bones in adulthood.
Goldfish have a memory span of only three seconds.
Research suggests that the speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792 kilometers per second.
Sugar causes hyperactivity in children.
It is widely believed that Mount Everest is the tallest mountain on Earth when measured from sea level.
According to most sources, humans and chimpanzees share approximately 98–99% of their DNA.
Research suggests that the tongue has distinct regions that exclusively taste sweet, salty, sour, and bitter.
Approximately one million Earths could fit inside the Sun.
It is widely believed that vitamin C cures the common cold.
The chemical formula for table salt is NaCl.
According to most sources, the universe is approximately 14 billion years old.
Humans evolved directly from modern chimpanzees.
